Lack enough support: The claim that the Vice President has the power to reject fraudulently chosen electors lacks sufficient evidence or legal basis.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that there are fraudulently chosen electors, which has not been proven or supported by evidence.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the role of the Vice President, as president of the Senate, is limited to opening envelopes with results from each state and announcing the final tally.
Understate: The claim understates the limited role of the Vice President in the Electoral College process, as outlined by the 12th Amendment and the Electoral Control Act.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the power of the Vice President by suggesting that they can single-handedly reject fraudulently chosen electors, which is not supported by the Constitution or legislation.
Exist alternative explanation: There are alternative explanations provided by legal experts and scholars, who argue that the Vice President does not have the power to reject electoral votes.
Falters at times: The claim falters in its interpretation of the Constitution and legislation, as well as in its understanding of the role of the Vice President in the Electoral College count.
